At-a-Glance: A calm, professional swarm call workflow protects people, bees, and your reputation. Screen, triage, and respond with clear comms and records.
Why it Matters: Efficient triage avoids wasted trips and unsafe situations.
Good public interactions turn rescues into customers and allies.
Objectives: Use a standard question set to confirm ‘honey bee swarm’ vs wasps/bumbles.
Assess safety, access, and ownership before dispatch.
Record details and follow a scripted on-site process.
What Good Looks Like: Caller form completed with photos when possible.
Clear go/no-go criteria and estimated arrival window.
On-site: PPE, containment box, and written handover.
Step-by-Step: 1) Intake: name, phone, exact location, height/access, bee photos, time spotted, behaviour.
2) Confirm species and stability (cluster vs flying). If uncertain: request close photo or short video.
3) Risk screen: power lines, traffic, private property permissions.
4) Dispatch: agree window; send pre-visit guidance (stay back, close windows, keep pets in).
5) On-site: assess, contain, collect; tidy and advise; leave info sheet.
6) Log and follow-up: confirm relocation site and aftercare.
Seasonality & Climate: Peak spring–early summer; hot weather increases hanging time risk.
Data & Thresholds: Minimum kit for dispatch: veil/jacket, box, sheet, brush, sprayer, secateurs, straps.
No-go: unsafe height without proper access/permits; live electrics; aggressive colonies without plan.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: ‘Bees in roof for years’ -> Not a swarm; advise removal specialist or sealed entry check.
Symptom: Small ball under eaves in spring -> Likely scout cluster; confirm and monitor 24 h.
Symptom: Wasps/paper nest -> Decline swarm service; signpost pest control if necessary.
Common Pitfalls: Driving without photos or adequate description.
No property permission or unclear ownership of swarm.
Tools & Techniques: Collection box, sheets, pruners, water mist, bee brush, nuc box, queen clip/cage.
Phone map pins and photo exchange with caller.
Safety & Compliance: Public liability cover; ladder and manual-handling safety.
Respect private property and obtain permission before entry.
Field Checklist: Access and safety confirmed; PPE packed.
Communications: Use a calm script: what you will do, how long, what they should do.
Further Reading: Association swarm call scripts and ID guides.
Local authority guidance on access and permits.
Notes: Keep a printable ‘Is it a honey bee swarm?’ one-pager to text or email callers.
